quiz.quizTitle: GCSE Triple Science Chemistry: Covalent Bonding Retrieval Quiz
quiz.summary: This quiz covers key concepts in Covalent Bonding (C2) as per the AQA GCSE Triple Science Chemistry specification. It includes a mix of recall and descriptive questions, focusing on the formation of covalent bonds, the structure and properties of giant covalent substances, small molecules, polymers, and their respective melting points. The quiz features two multiple-choice questions and four short-answer questions to test understanding of fundamental chemical structures and bonding.
quiz.subject: chemistry

questions.explanation: Covalent bonds are formed when atoms share electrons to achieve a stable outer shell, typically occurring between non-metal atoms.
questions.sourceReference: C2 questions, Q1; C2 answers, Q1

questions.prompt: Which type of atoms form covalent bonds between them?
questions.explanation: Covalent bonds are formed specifically between non-metal atoms, as they both need to gain electrons to achieve a full outer shell, which they do by sharing.
questions.sourceReference: C2 questions, Q2; C2 answers, Q2

questions.prompt: Describe the structure and bonding of a giant covalent substance.
questions.answer: Billions of atoms bonded together by strong covalent bonds.
questions.explanation: Giant covalent substances consist of billions of atoms bonded together by strong covalent bonds, forming a vast network.
questions.sourceReference: C2 questions, Q3; C2 answers, Q3

questions.prompt: Describe the structure and bonding of small molecules.
questions.answer: Small numbers of atoms group together into molecules with strong covalent bonds between the atoms and weak intermolecular forces between the molecules.
questions.explanation: Small molecules are formed from small numbers of atoms grouped together by strong covalent bonds, but the forces between individual molecules (intermolecular forces) are weak.
questions.sourceReference: C2 questions, Q4; C2 answers, Q4

questions.prompt: Describe the structure and bonding of polymers.
questions.answer: Many identical molecules joined together by strong covalent bonds in a long chain, with weak intermolecular forces between the chains.
questions.explanation: Polymers consist of many identical molecules (monomers) joined together by strong covalent bonds to form long chains. There are weak intermolecular forces between these chains.
questions.sourceReference: C2 questions, Q5; C2 answers, Q5

questions.prompt: Why do giant covalent substances have high melting points?
questions.answer: It takes a lot of energy to break the strong covalent bonds between the atoms.
questions.explanation: Giant covalent substances have high melting points because a large amount of energy is required to overcome the strong covalent bonds that extend throughout the entire structure.
questions.sourceReference: C2 questions, Q6; C2 answers, Q6
